Every two weeks, the '22 de Julio' community bank meet in Picoaza parish, in the city of Portoviejo.  This area is known for being a very commercial area.  It is also known for its traditional San Pedro and San Pablo celebrations and the cheerfulness of its people.

This is where Betty lives.  She is 59 years old, married, and has four children who are all grown up.  Two of her children still live with her.  Her husband is a salesman.

Betty is a very good wife and mother who is requesting this loan for the family business.  Her family has a business where they sell all kinds of car parts, lubricants, brake fluid, etc.  They work every day, from Monday to Friday, from 8.00am to 6.00pm.  They also work Saturdays and Sundays until 1.00pm.  They buy their spare parts and products in Guayaquil and Manta.  Betty's children help her in the business.  They have had their business for 18 years and it has made them very good income.

Betty will use this loan to buy tires, spare parts, brake fluid etc.  This is the second loan cycle that Betty has been a member of her community bank and she likes the bank for the help that they provide through the loans.

Betty's dream is to own her own premises as the premises where their business is currently located are rented.  This takes away a good part of their profits.

loans.use: to buy tires, spare parts, brake fluid, etc.

loans.name: Sabougnouman Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe SABOUGNOUMAN II sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Zagnanabougou, un des villages de la commune de Guegneka,  préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont le mil, l’arachide et le fonio. Elles sont à leur sixième collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, FATI deuxième personne à partir de la droite dans le rang des assises, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 0,75 hectare de mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Fana,  après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 100 000F CFA environs par campagne.

loans.use: Labour, semence, engrais, herbicide, sarclage et petits équipements

loans.name: Eric Herman

texts.fr: Eric est un homme de 33 ans célibataire et père d'un enfant de 7 ans. Ses enfants vont à l'école. comme activité, il dispose d'un snack bar dans un quartier de la capitale depuis 02 ans environ. Il bénéficie d'une bonne expérience dans le domaine. mais son capital ne lui permet plus de satisfaire toute sa clientèle qui est parfois obligée de se retourner vers la concurrence. Ceci à cause de la petitesse de son capital. Il voudrait avec ce crédit pour augmenter les casiers de boissons et des liqueurs afin de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. cela va également augmenter son chiffre d'affaire ainsi que son bénéfice et lui permettra aussi d'être en règle dans son commerce. les revenus générés lui permettront de mieux subvenir aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Éric is a 33-year-single man and father of one; his child is seven years old and goes to school. For about two years, he has been running a snack bar in one of the city’s neighborhood. He boasts a good amount of experience in his domain, but his capital no longer allows him to meet customer demand, so his clients sometimes have to buy from competitors. This is due to his small capital.

With this loan, he would like to increase his stock of beverages and liquor to better meet his clientele’s demand. This will increase his sales as well as profits, and help his business be in good standing. The generated income will make it possible for him to takes better care of his family.

loans.use: to increase his stock of beers and liquor.

loans.name: Felinas Group

texts.es:
En diversas regiones de Oaxaca los ingenios azucareros representan la actividad económica más importante, existen desde la época colonial y forman parte de la identidad de los habitantes. Cerca de uno de estos ingenios se consolidó el grupo Felinas con diez integrantes dedicadas a distintas actividades pero con un mismo fin: mejorar su calidad de vida. El grupo lo integran: Trinidad quien vende lencería por catálogo; Ma. Victoria, cosméticos; Venancia, perfumes y carne de puerco; Jessica, ropa y dulces; Alexis, tamales; Amada, dulces; Claudio, carne de cerdo; María, medicamentos además de ofrecer servicio de enfermería; María Luisa, tacos y Anayanci quien maneja una estética. 

   María Luisa, mejor conocida como Licha, está casada con Vicente quien trabaja en el ingenio azucarero de la comunidad; aunque aún no son padres tienen fe en que pronto llegará un pequeño a su familia. 

   Licha aprovechó la falta de negocios cercanos y el gusto de todo mexicano por los tacos para iniciar su propia taquería. Los fines de semana, a las 6:00 pm en punto, coloca el comal sobre la parrilla caliente y prepara la carne de bistec, longaniza y enchilada; mientras que en otra mesa ya tiene listos los ingredientes que no pueden faltar en cualquier puesto de tacos: los limones, la salsa, la sal y las indispensables tortillas. 

   Anteriormente Licha ha invertido capital para adquirir mobiliario y utensilios necesarios en su negocio. Hoy necesita el préstamo para comprar dos mesas más y ocho sillas. Además piensa instalar una lona para que su taquería se extienda. “Con el apoyo de mi esposo, mi sazón y un buen trato al cliente la taquería seguirá creciendo, quizás venderé todos los días y tendré algunos ayudantes” comentó Licha entusiasmada.
   
El grupo Felinas agradece de antemano el interés mostrado en sus actividades las cuales fortalecerán con los apoyos otorgados.

*En la fotografía Licha muestra la parrilla donde prepara los tacos, viste blusa negra y se encuentra detrás de Jessica quien viste blusa roja.

loans.use: Comprara; 2 mesas, 8 sillas y una lona

loans.name: Jose Mardo

texts.es:
José manifiesta que con el aporte del crédito anterior ha tenido a su alcance materiales necesarios para poder mejorar el taller de estructuras metálicas, cumplió con muchos pedidos que le hicieron sus clientes y sus ingresos se mantienen estables.
Por tener una experiencia satisfactoria con el crédito anterior nuevamente solicita más capital para comprar hierro, laminas, electrodos, pintura, etc., para fabricar puertas, ventanas, portones y balcones, con la inversión mantendrá el taller de estructuras metálicas en el mercado y sus clientes seguirán prefiriendo sus servicios.

loans.use: comprar hierro, laminas, electrodos, pintura, etc., para fabricar puertas, ventanas, portones y balcones

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria P. is a native of Guayaquil, Ecuador, and she runs a small shop that sells food items and drinks. This mother of two children, one of whom still depends on her financially, is a homeowner. Located in her house, “Tienda Jenny” is a bustling little store that sells to customers in the neighborhood in need of candy, juices, and soda. With 20 years of experience managing her shop, Gloria is a local favorite. Many of the young children that attend the school across the street come to her store after class. Working from 6 a.m. until 8 p.m. Gloria is a hard-working, entrepreneurial woman. She is asking for a $575 loan to buy more products for her store and diversify the supply.

loans.use: Gloria needs this loan to diversify her product inventory and purchase items which school children request

loans.name: Jose Dolores

texts.en:
Don José Dolores is the father of a family with six sons, living in the area of San Juanito, in the state of Chihuahua. Many years ago he began a small business selling groceries from his own home, with the support of his wife. With the time the business has grown little by little. Thanks to the activity of his store he has been able to pay for the education of his sons, which would have otherwise been impossible.

At this moment he is asking for a loan of $475 in order to purchase more merchandise and in this way attract more clients. Do not doubt him, you have the possibility to help Jose Dolores and his family, and they would be sincerely thankful for your support.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Don José Dolores es padre de familia, de 6 hijos, ellos viven en la localidad de San Juanito, en el estado de Chihuahua. Hace muchos años el comenzó con un pequeño negocio de venta de abarrotes en su propio domicilio, con el apoyo activo de su esposa. Con el paso de tiempo ha ido creciendo poco a poco. Gracias a esta actividad ha podido solventar los gastos de los estudios de sus hijos, que de otra forma no hubiera sido posible.

En este momento el requiere de un préstamo de 475 dlls para poder comprar más mercancía y de esta manera atraer a más clientes. No lo dudes más, tú tienes la posibilidad de ayudar a José Dolores y a su familia, ellos agradecen tu apoyo sinceramente.

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan has been working on this farm his entire life. He lives with his wife and 9 year old daughter, and helps his other two children who are grown up and independent. He relies completely on rice farming to feed his family, as his lands are only productive for this activity. He was born and raised in Baba and learned to farm rice from his father. He wants to make his land more productive by plowing them with rented machinery. In the long run, he wants to save for his daughter’s education.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of one the new Communal Banks formed in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Anzuelo Baba Communal Bank are part of an association of rice farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their organization, El Anzuelo Asociacion, works cooperatively to help their members cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. Most recently, El Anzuelo was able to start a program that improved their members access to watering services..

The members of La Asociacion El Anzuelo de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Baba

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice farming

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en:
Mrs. Chuon S. is 30 years old and mother of 1 child. She lives with her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. To support her family, she has two sources of income. First, she sells cooked food and rice along the roadside in her area. Second, she rents some rooms of her house to local garment workers. The two sources bring in an average of $3.50 per day in revenue, while her husband can typically earn around $5 each day from working at a small private company as a security guard.

In order to maximize her family's savings, Mrs. Chuon would like to add more rooms to rent out to the workers, which would give her additional income. She is currently requesting a loan in the amount of $1000 to purchase construction supplies such as cement, bricks, wood, zinc, and sand in order to build rooms to rent. In the future, she dreams of being able to expand her business and send her children to university.

loans.use: To add more rooms to rent out to garment workers in her area

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es:
Lidia Y. works making clothing and other items out of leather, such as jackets, wallets, and other accessories which she sells on Tumusla Street in the city of La Paz.

Ever since she was very young she worked at this trade, learning the art from her parents. Lidia intends to turn her life around, now that she has two children to support.

At present Lidia is an exporter of leather clothing and accessories. Her articles are taken to Puerto Suarez in Brazil. For this reason, she she must complete a certain number of items per day. That's why she already has two employees helping her with the work.

Lidia needs capital in increase her acquisition of materials, which is the only way she can fill the demand for exportation. Only in this way can she increase her income and her quality of life, by establishing her work and making it into a business enterprise.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

Lidia Y. se dedica a la confección y costura de prendas en cuero, como ser chamarras, carteras y otros accesorios que vende en la calle Tumusla de la ciudad de La Paz.

Desde muy niña que se dedica a este rubro, aprendiendo el arte de sus padres, Lidia intenta darle un giro a su vida, puesto que ahora tiene dos hijos que mantener.

En la actualidad Lidia es exportadora de prendas y accesorios de cuero, sus prendas son llevadas a Puerto Suarez en la república de Brasil. Para esto, ella necesariamente debe cumplir con un número de prendas confeccionadas por día, por esta razón es que ya tiene dos dependientes que le colaboran en el trabajo.

Lidia necesita de capital para incrementar la adquisición de materiales, que es la única manera de poder cumplir con la demande que la exportación le exige. Solo de esta forma podrá mejorar sus ingresos y su calidad de vida, logrando establecer su negocio y convertirlo en una empresa.

loans.use: Lidia needs capital to increase her acquisition of materials, which is the only way to meet the demand for exportation.

loans.name: Eng

texts.en: Mrs. Eng S., age 49, is a widow who works selling scarves at the market to make about $4.85 each day. She has three children, two of whom are married and have moved away from home, and one who works in construction making $50 per month. In order to expand her inventory to meet growing customer demand, she would like to request a loan of $700 to purchase her inventory in bulk and thus get better prices. She is pictured with her son in the photograph.

loans.use: To purchase scarves to expand her business.

loans.name: Dilafruz

texts.en:
J. Dilafruz is the mother of two children. She lives with her parents as she is divorced. Her parents are pensioners and she supports all of them by her activity; trade of fabrics. She tries to make sure that her children do not need anything nor feel the shortage of a father's love. Her parents take care of her children when she is at her work and try to help their daughter as they can.

Her business loacted in J.Rasulov Clothing Market district of Khujand,Tadjikistan. She has been engaged in business for over 5 years and she has good experience as a skillful seller. Her turnover is fast and she has many regular clients. Currently she saves money for her boy's circumcision party (musulman tradition) in February.

From Kiva she is requesting extra capital for increasing the volume of her fabrics and making a good profit.

loans.use: Business expansion.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs. Sim S., 48, is a widow and lives with her three unemployed children in Bathambong province, Cambodia. To cover her family's expenses, she works as a tailor and typically makes about $5/day.  Her customer base is mostly the people in her community. Sim S. has recently requested for a loan to purchase more cloth, sewing thread and tools for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase more cloth, sewing thread and tools for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Agip B 2006(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Martha is a single mother of two children. She has a beauty salon. She wants to use the extra busienss profits to pay school fees for the children and also improve her home. S. sells fresh fish while Gorette has a retail shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand her saloon

loans.name: Rajabaly

texts.ru:
Rajabaly S. lives in the city of Yavan. He is 38 years old, is married and has 5 children. He has finished high school. Rajabaly currently sells fruits and vegetables at the market called "Mehrgon". He purchases produce from wholesale traders and then sells it in smaller quantities. He has been in this business for about 8 years. This is the only source of income for his family, which is why Rajabaly never misses the opportunity to make more money. With his loan he plans to increase the volume of goods. Rajabaly plans to repay his loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Сулаймонов Раджабали проживает в городе Яван. Возраст 38 лет , женат имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее, занимается торговлей фруктов и овощей на рынке "Мехргон" . Скупает товар у оптовых реализаторов и продает в розницу. Занимается этим видом бизнеса около 8 лет. Это единственный источник дохода у его семьи , поэтому он не упускает никакой возможности заработать больше. Планирует получить кредит для того чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Increase the volume of produce

loans.name: Bangali T.

texts.en: Bangali is 33 years old and has three children who would also like to become commercial farmers.  He already received one loan from SMT and wisely invested 75% of the loan on labour and the remaining 25% on fertilizer.  As a result of that loan, he boasts that he harvested 45 bags of pigeon peas (rather than the 15 bags that he was harvesting before the loan), 20 bags of which he was able to sell to the neighbouring country of Guinea.  Further, his income increased on account of the first loan and he feels fortunate that he will have enough food for his family until next season.  He is seeking this loan to expand his farm.

loans.use: To expand his farm in order to continue to increase production

loans.name: Tomasina's Group

texts.en:
Tomasina is a hard-working woman and the proud mother of two beautiful sons. Recently, Tomasina decided to start a business selling house wares and kitchen items to the women of her community. Her business allows her to supplement the family’s income and helps her husband face their financial burdens. Tomasina plans on using her loan to add new items to her stock in order to increase her sales volume and her income. Tomasina says she’d like to buy a house so that her children can live comfortably, but that’s down the road.

Tomasina has requested this loan together with the following women:

Ana B. L., an active entrepreneur who sells women’s clothing.

Teofila L. S., who will use the money to buy shoes and pants for her small store.

Marileidy J. M., who sells clothing.

Luisa S. G., who will buy clothing in bulk.

Order of appearance in the picture, left to right: Ana B. L., Tomasina T. M., Teofila L. S., Marileidy J. M. and Luisa S. G.

loans.use: To purchase inventory to resell in the community

loans.name: Kossi Michel

texts.fr:
Kossi Michel K. is 31 years old, married, and a dad. He is a farmer in Kuma, a small village in the mountains near Kpalimé, one of the biggest cities in Togo. Since he is a farmer, he has trouble providing for his family's needs because arable lands are becoming more and more rare and less fertile. He grows yams and corn in his field, which is found about 10 km from his house. To do his work better, Kossi Michel hopes to use this loan to buy a motorbike to transport himself to the field more easily. He appreciates the opportunity that this loan will give him to improve the quality of his life.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur Kossi Michel K. est âgé de 31 ans, marié et père. Il est un cultivateur à Kuma, un petit village dans les montagnes environnantes de Kpalimé, une des plus grandes villes du Togo. Comme il est un cultivateur, il subvient difficilement aux besoins de la famille puisque les terres cultivables deviennent de plus en plus rares et moins fertiles. Il cultive les ignames et du mais dans son champ, qui se trouve environ 10 kilomètres de sa maison. Pour mieux faire son travail, Kossi Michel espère avec ce crédit acheter une moto pour lui transporter au champ plus facilement. Il apprécie l’opportunité que ce crédit va lui donner pour améliorer la qualité de sa vie.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for transportation to his field

loans.name: Jocelyne

texts.fr:
Born on June 23, 1971 in COTONOU, Ms. Jocelyne H. is married to Honoré KOUTON, a caretaker at the Ministry of Justice, Legislation, and Human Rights. The couple have four children, all in school, including the eldest in the 6th grade, and the other three are in elementary school. She has been residing in the Habitat district of Cotonou for about nine years. A seller of various goods for a dozen years, Ms. Jocelyne H. started in the catering business a year ago. In order to bolster her business, she requested an initial loan of 30,000 francs CFA in 2006. She improved a great deal in selling various goods, and the catering is coming along just as nicely for her. At present, she is requesting a fifth loan, in the amount of 100,000 francs, to meet the expectations of her customers.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née le 23 juin 1971 à COTONOU, dame H. Jocelyne est mariée à KOUTON Honoré, agent d’entretien au Ministère de la Justice, de la Législation et des Droits de l’Homme. Le couple a quatre enfants tous scolarisés dont l’aîné en classe de 6ème et les trois autres au cours primaire. EIle réside au quartier Habitat de Cotonou il y a environ neuf ans. Vendeuse de divers depuis une dizaine d’années, dame H. Jocelyne s’est lancée dans la restauration il y a un an. Afin de renforcer son activité, elle a sollicité en 2006 un premier prêt de 30.000fcfa. Elle a beaucoup évolué dans la vente de divers et la restauration marche aussi bien pour elle. A présent, elle sollicite pour son 5ème prêt un montant de 100.000fcfa afin de répondre aux attentes de sa clientèle.

loans.use: To buy two sacks of corn, one sack of rice, and various goods

loans.name: Construction, Livestock Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Hong Thi C. is 30 years old. She is a farmer and also raise livestock. Her family owns an automobile which they use to transport construction materials for people in the area. The four other members of her group have done very well in their repayments in the first round. In this second round of participation, she is requesting 3,808,000 VND to supplement her capital to buy construction materials to sell.

Her group includes:

  • Mrs. Tien Thi N., requesting 3,808,000 VND to buy a breeding pig.
  • Mrs. Oanh Thi N., requesting 3,808,000 VND to buy goods to sell at a general store.
  • Mrs. Loan Thi N., requesting 3,808,000 VND to buy chicken feed.
  • Mrs. Hue Thi N., requesting 3,186,000 VND to buy chicken feed.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Chi N., Kiva volunteer.

    Chị C. Thị Hồng (MS: 09050031), năm nay 30 tuổi. Chị vùa làm ruộng vừa chăn nuôi. Nhà chị có ô tô để đi chở vật liệu xây dưng cho bà con trong vùng. Bốn thành viên trong nhóm chị đã hoàn trả rất tốt C. kỳ một. Lần này tham gia C. kỳ hai chị vay 3.808.000 VND để bổ sung vốn mua vật liêu xây dưng bán.

    Trong nhóm chị còn có

  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Tiền (MS: 09050033), vay 3.808.000 VND để mua lợn giống.
  • Chị Ngô Thị Oanh (MS: 09050032), vay 3.808.000 VND để mua hàng tạp hóa bán.
  • Chị Ngô Thị Loan (MS: 09050030), vay 3.808.000 VND để mua cám lợn.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Huệ ( MS: 09050083), vay 3.186.000 VND để mua cám lợn

loans.use: Construction materials, raising livestock, and investing in business

loans.name: Fortunata Dominga

texts.es:
Fortunata Dominga is 26 years old and completed some schooling when she was younger. She lives with her husband and their 3 children in Tacna, Mazcruz.

She is a member of the communal bank Julia J. in Mazocruz, and with her first loan she was able to purchase meat which she sold at a profit. With some capital saved, they also began a blacksmith business which she and her husband now run together.

With the new loan, which she will repay in 4 payments, they will buy supplies for their blacksmith business and continue to increase their income. Fortunata's dream is to have her own stable where she can raise animals, and earn enough money to provide a good education for her children.

Fortunata Dominga tiene 26 años de edad, estudió tercero de secundaría, es conveniente, madre de tres hijos que aún dependen de ella, vive en la Av. Tacna s/n – Mazocruz. Es socia del Banco Comunal Julia Jiménez – Mazocruz, Distrito de Santa Rosa, Provincia del Collao – Puno, con su primer crédito compró 02 cabezas de de alpaca, desde el año 2,003 al 2,007 hacía negocio de venta de carne de alpaca, llama, el cual entregaba a los intermediarios de Tacna todos los miércoles y viernes, semanalmente vendía de 10 a 15 degollados, poco a poco aumentó su capital, ahora cuenta con un taller de metal mecánica confecciona puertas, ventanas metálicas conjuntamente con su esposo. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 Nuevos Soles, que pagará en 04 cuotas, tiene planificado comprar 08 planchas galvanizadas y 11 varillas de fierro para confección de puertas y ventanas. Su mayor sueño es tener su establo de ganado vacuno para engorde y educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales.

loans.use: TO PURCHASE SUPPLIES FOR HER BLACKSMITH BUSINESS, INCREASE  HER INCOME AND EARN ENOUGH TO PROVIDE A GOOD EDUCATION FOR HER CHILDREN.

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: Née le 17/09/1967 à Allada, dame B. Christine est mariée à GANDOLANHOU Octave employé à la SOBEMAP. Mère de 04 enfants dont 03 scolarisés et 01 pas encore en âge d’être scolarisé, elle est une femme battante. Elle est dans cette activité de vente de divers produits de consommation courante depuis 17 ans et vit à Abokicodji depuis 22 ans. Compte tenu de l'évolution de son activité et aussi de la demande de plus en plus croissante et pressante de sa clientèle, dame B. Christine sollicite à son sixième prêt un montant de 190000 F CFA.
texts.en:
Born on September 17, 1967 in Allada, Mrs. Christine B. is married to Octave Gandolanhou, who is an employee of SOBEMAP. The mother of 4 children of whom 3 are enrolled in school and one is still too young to go to school, she is a courageous woman. She has been selling various staples for 17 years and has lived in Abokicodji for 22 years. Considering the evolution of her business and the ever growing demand from her insistant customers, Mrs. Christine B. is requesting her 6th loan in the amount of 190,000 F CFA.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of tinned tomatoes, a case of sugar, and a case of sweetened condensed milk

loans.name: María Yolanda

texts.es:
La señora María Yolanda tiene 40 años de edad, vive en Manuel Cox 112, Pueblo Joven Aurora Díaz, distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú y pertenece al Banco Comunal Auroras en Acción.
Estudió hasta segundo año de educación secundaria y no continuo debido a que sus padres no podían apoyarla porque eran muy pobres. Se casó con el señor Fernando Azabache y tienen 2 hijos,  los dos dependen de sus padres.
Empezó su negocio vendiendo juguetes, luego empezó a vender menú y veía que rendía más, pero no tenia capital. Una amiga la invitó a participar en los bancos comunales del Movimiento Manuela Ramos y desde ese día todo cambio tremendamente, la señora se capitalizó. El negocio lo realiza en su casa.
El primer monto que recibió como crédito fue de 300 soles, el cual devolvió en 4 cuotas, y lo invirtió en la compra de juguetes.
Con este crédito de 300 soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, implementará su negocio con miras a mejorarlo.
Su sueño es tener su propio negocio e implementarlo .
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Yolanda is 40 years old and lives at 112 Manuel Cox, in the village of Aurora Diaz, in the district of Salaverry, in the province of Trujillo in the suburb of La Libertad, Perú. She belongs to the Auroras in action community bank. She studied through the second year of secondary school, but was forced to stop because her parents could no longer support her because they were very poor. Maria married Fernando Azabache and they have 2 children, who are their dependents. Maria began her business by selling toys, and later began to sell food as she saw that it was more profitable, but she did not have the capital. A friend invited Maria to participate in the Manuela Ramos Movement community bank and since that day everything completely changed, she capitalized. Maria operates her business out of her house. The first loan she received was 300 soles, which she repaid in 4 months, and used to purchase toys to sell. With this 300 soles loan, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will invest in her business to improve it. Her dream is to run her own business.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improve her business

loans.name: Channa

texts.en: Mrs. Channa S. is a 25-year-old mother of a small child in Trapeang Chouk village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Nup SoKum, is a construction worker who earns a small salary.  Their rice paddy is infertile and yields a poor crop. In order to deal this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to make her soil more productive.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Khan

texts.en:
Mrs. Khan C., 25, is married and lives with her husband and one child in Bathambong Province, Cambodia. She started a grocery business in 2006. She usually buys wholesale grocery products from a market in her town and starts re-selling them to the people in her community. From her activity, she can typically make on average US$ 3/day in income.

Meanwhile, her husband is employed by a private company as a driver, making US$ 150 per month. For her household expenses, Mrs. C. spends on average US$ 50 on food, US$ 15 on utilities, and US$ 15 on her business transportation.

Presently, Mrs. C. is asking for a loan to keep expanding her inventory to meet her customer demand.

loans.use: To buy more products to expand her inventory

loans.name: Fofoga

texts.en: Fofoga A., 31, is married and has four children.  She has many years of experience in the School Canteen business. She sells to the students five days per week. She has had three previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 800 Tala ($333 US).  SPBD loans are Fofoga’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase boxes of chicken, bunches of bananas, sacks of taro, and a large cooler in which to store ice-cakes and drinks. One of her daughters is helping her with the business.

loans.use: Purchase cooking stove, chicken, bananas, taro and a large cooler

loans.name: Sitheavy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sitheavy R., 37, and her husband, Mr. Norm Yem, 46, live in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1995 and have two children, a son and a daughter, who are still small.

Sitheavy has been selling grocery items for two years. She buys them from Chbar Ampov market, located in Phnom Penh, for resale at her home. Her husband is a village chief.

Sitheavy is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Nem

texts.en: Mrs. Nem T. lives in Serei Douch village in Takeo province. She is a rice middleman in the local village. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more rice to re-sell to earn more profit. Her husband, Mr. Chhroeung Sun, is a farmer who owns a piece of land where he cultivaT. rice. Mrs. Nem T. is 52 years old and the mother of six children, five of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other is a laborer. Her husband is with her in the picture.

loans.use: to buy more rice to re-sell

loans.name: Pinamang

texts.en:
Pinamang A. is a 20-year-old young lady. She is single and enjoys trading, the business through which she makes a living. She completed junior high school but could not further her education due to financial difficulty. She decided to learn a trade and started selling little things like palm oil, vegetables oil, tomatoes, onions etc. on top of a table in front of their family house at Kwahu Da, a farming community in the Eastern region of Ghana.

Pinamang trades to support her mother and take care of her siblings in school. She buys boxes of tomatoes, peppers, etc from farmers who come from surrounding villages. She sells them at affordable prices. She sells mostly to households and food vendors in her community. She has been in business for the past three years. She wants a loan to buy oil and vegetables in large quantities so she can increase her profit margin.

She is a member of the community group called Heaven. Members in this group guarantee loans for one another and support one another in handling repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To procure tomatoes, palm oil, onions etc. in bulk.

loans.name: Maria Del Socorro

texts.es:
Con mucha dedicación a su labor, en el municipio de Somotillo la señora María P. ha iniciado el mejoramiento de su vivienda siendo esta labor el sueño que por mucho tiempo ha tenido y son sus objetivos brindarle las mejores condiciones de vida a sus tres pequeños hijos que tanto ama.

Por lo antes dicho, la señora María P. ha buscado el apoyo en Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito para la compra de los materiales de construcción y de esta manera ir mejorando poco a poco las condiciones de vida propia y la de su amada familia en el municipio de Somotillo.
texts.en:
With diligence and hard work, Señora María P. has begun to make improvements to her house in the town of Somotillo. She has dreamed of doing this for a long time and her objective is to provide better living conditions for her three small children who she loves so much. To do that, she has sought the support of Ceprodel to obtain a loan for the purchase of construction materials. In this way, little by little, she is going to improve her own life and that of her beloved family in the town of Somotillo.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina has been selling soup ingredients in Warri, Delta state, Nigeria since 1997. She is 39 years old and married with 3 children.She hopes to get a loan of N100,000 to purchase additional soup ingredients to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more soup ingredients to sell

loans.name: Aissatou Aimady

texts.fr: Aissatou Aimady, 49 ans est mariée avec 06 enfants  en charge. Elle est membre du banc villageois de Sinthiang Coundara depuis 6 ans. Son activité est la restauration et la vente de pâte d’arachide. Elle compte acheter des provisions pour préparer les repas et acheter des arachides à  transformer en pâte d’arachide et vendre. Elle veut  renforcer son captal pour mieux assurer les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Aissatou Aimady, age 49, is married and has six children in her care. She has been a member of the village lending group of Sinthiang Coundara for six years. Her works in food catering and in selling peanut butter. She plans to buy provisions to make meals and to buy peanuts for processing into peanut butter to sell. She wants to boost her capital to make sure she can cover family expenses better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies and peanuts for producing peanut butter and making meals

loans.name: Gulzamon

texts.en:
Gulzamon is married with 3 children. She sells nice, quality fabrics for national dresses at a big local market. Her husband (pictured) is actively helping her with her business which she started about 10 years ago. Gulzamon would like to ask for a loan of 6800 Somoni to increase her inventory stock which will help supply her until the summer season. She believes this timely investment will help her generate additional income and increase the family budget. IMON International believes Gulzamon’s responsible nature and strong character will assist her in the current loan repayment. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more fabrics for her business.

loans.name: Maravilla Group

texts.es:
La asociación denominada “Maravilla” trabaja junto a Pro-Mujer hace siete años, se reúnen cada dos semanas en el centro focal Los andes, ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto, a la fecha  cuenta con doce miembros. Con la ayuda de su asistente de créditos realizan sus actividades de forma responsable.
Diferentes son las actividades de esta asociación, como ser la venta de abarrotes, venta  de ropa ligera, costura de ropa, sabanas y cortinas, venta de carne de res, víveres y otros . Desean ampliar sus ventas, para esto necesitan comprar mercadería o materia prima al por mayor, están seguros que  mejoraran  sus ganancias y puedan cubrir  los gastos que tienen en sus hogares.
texts.en:
The association named “Wonder” has worked with Pro-Mujer for the past 7 years; they get together every two weeks in the main center Los Andes, located in the city of El Alto. Currently the group consists of twelve members. With the help of their loan counselor they carry out their activities in a responsible manner. This association carries out different activities, such as, the sale of groceries, the sale of light clothing, sewing clothing, blankets, and curtains, the sale of meat, supplies, and others. They would like to expand their sales, and for that the need to purchase merchandise or basic materials wholesale. They are certain that they will improve their earnings and will be able to cover their household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise or basic materials.

loans.name: Laila

texts.en:
Laila P. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 37 years old. Laila is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Laila manufactures and sells clay products to local businesses and community members. Laila has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Laila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. She use the previous loan to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Laila is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP that she will use to purchase additional inventory and serve as working capital. This will be Laila's third loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Geraline

texts.en:
Geraline H. is from the village of Katipa, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Geraline is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Geraline owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling bananacue to the local community. Geraline has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Geraline joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Geraline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. Geraline is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Geraline from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale
